definition: to keep an appointment/to keep one's word
to guard/to defend/to keep watch/to abide by the law/to observe (rules or ritual)/nearby/adjoining
to make an appointment/to invite/approximately/pact/treaty/to economize/to restrict/to reduce (a fraction)/concise
to weigh in a balance or on a scale

sentences.english: I managed to persuade quite a few people to see me, and I must keep the appointments.
sentences.chinese: 我好不容易说服了那么多人和我会面，我必须守约呀。

sentences.english: People who keep appointments are considered dependable .
sentences.chinese: 守约的人被认为是可靠的人。

sentences.english: I get asked all of the time by salespeople how to make sure that prospects keep their appointments.
sentences.chinese: 一直有销售员问我，怎样才能确保客户能守约。

sentences.english: I'm very punctual. March is my sweetheart.
sentences.chinese: 我很守约，三月，是我的情郎。

sentences.english: Specify the real or implied commitment that was broken.
sentences.chinese: 详细陈述不守约的明示的或暗示的承诺。

sentences.english: The default interest shall be allocated to the non-defaulting Parties prorata to their shareholdings.
sentences.chinese: 该违约利息由各守约方按其股权比例分配。

sentences.english: Keeping one's appointment is regarded as a virtue in many cultures.
sentences.chinese: 在许多文化中守约都是一种美德。

sentences.english: People who don't keep appointments are considered unreliable.
sentences.chinese: 不守约的人被认为是不可信赖的。

definition: Houyi, mythological Chinese archer whose wife was Chang'e
Sun Bin (-316 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (425-221 BC)
Ying Zheng (260-210 BC), personal name of the first emperor 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2]

Di Renjie (607-700), Tang dynasty politician, prime minister under Wu Zetian, subsequently hero of legends/master sleuth Judge Dee, aka Chinese Sherlock Holmes, in novel Three murder cases solved by Judge Dee 狄公案[Di2 gong1 an4] translated by Dutch sinologist R.H. van Gulik 高羅珮|高罗佩[Gao1 Luo2 pei4]

Guan Yu (-219), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, fearsome fighter famous for virtue and loyalty/posthumously worshipped and identified with the guardian Bodhisattva Sangharama
Han Xin (-196 BC), famous general of first Han emperor Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1]
秦越人[Qin2 Yue4 ren2] (407-310 BC), Warring States physician known for his medical skills, nicknamed Bian Que after the earliest known Chinese physician allegedly from the 黃帝|黄帝[Huang2 di4] era

Jiang Ziya (c. 1100 BC, dates of birth and death unknown), partly mythical sage advisor to King Wen of Zhou 周文王[Zhou1 Wen2 wang2] and purported author of “Six Secret Strategic Teachings” 六韜|六韬[Liu4 tao1], one of the Seven Military Classics of ancient China 武經七書|武经七书[Wu3 jing1 Qi1 shu1]
Huang Zhong (-220), general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, portrayed as an old fighter
Jing Ke (-227 BC), celebrated in verse and fiction as would-be assassin of King Ying Zheng of Qin 秦嬴政 (later the First Emperor 秦始皇)
Zhang Fei (168-221), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, famous as fearsome fighter and lover of wine
to keep promises
courtesy name of Zhuge Liang 諸葛亮|诸葛亮[Zhu1 ge3 Liang4]

Zhuge Liang (181-234), military leader and prime minister of Shu Han 蜀漢|蜀汉 during the Three Kingdoms period/the main hero of the fictional Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义, where he is portrayed as a sage and military genius/mastermind
to speak and keep one's promise (idiom); as good as one's word
Nüwa (creator of humans in Chinese mythology)
